messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "sam.gribbles" <sam.gribbles@...> wrote:
>
> Hi All,
>
> I'm new to Junit testing and have been able to do some basic testing
> etc.
> What I want to do now is test for objects that are returned in random
> order. E.G. I have a few Fortune Cookies that are stored in an array of
> Strings. I've written some code that returns them randomly.
> What is the best method for testing? i.e. should I be using Mocks?
> If anybody has any good examples or relevant web sites please let me
> know.
>
> Your help is greatly appreciated.
>
> Sam.
>

Testing random (or more generally, non-deterministic) behavior is an
interesting question, and one I like to ask during interviews. We
could talk for hours about it, but I have a feeling you are looking
for a practical answer.

If you can seed the random number generator (you probably should), you
can easily test the following:

- Two sequences with the same seed produce the same fortune cookies in
the same order.

- Two sequences with different seeds produce different sequences of
fortune cookies.

You should also test for invariant properties (i.e. things that should
always happen or never happen). For example, request a fortune cookie
a large number of times and make sure that it always returns a "valid"
string. You can define a valid string as a non-null, non-empty string
or, even better, every string you return should be in the set of
fortune cookies strings you are using. The latter implies that the
set of fortune cookies strings should not include null or empty
strings - which sounds like a good property of a fortune cookie
generator (unless you have a nihilistic view of life) and something
else that you should test.

There are many other very interesting techniques for testing
randomness, but I think they might be overkill for a fortune cookie
generator. But if you are interested in learning more about this type
of testing, I wrote a chapter on testing for the O'Reilly book
"Beautiful Code" which covers some of these ideas. Here's a link to it:

http://junitfactory.com/articles/beautiful-code/BeautifulTests.pdf

I hope this helps,

Alberto
